KNOW MORE

About me

I am a interaction designer and developer, who is extremely enthusiastic about blockchain and cryptocurrency. I work with Front-End technologies, specifically HTML, CSS and JavaScript. I am constantly learning blockchain technologies, such as Solidity, to understand secure smart contracts and the growing blockchain ecosystem.

I aspire to be a Full-Stack Blockchain developer, who has the UX/UI process of an Interaction Designer. I believe that these 2 skills compliment each other well, and can provide value to businesses looking to solve problems through the use of these technologies.

View Resume

Projects

Client Portfolio Website

This was a project for a 3rd year student, who is a photographer and animator. He wanted a portfolio website, in which He could showcase his photography collections as well as a few portraits - which were animated self portraits. This was A really fun project, with it being my first client website and working with awesome photography made the experience a interesting and great experience. It was built using HTML and CSS, making use of CSS animations to make it slightly more dynamic.

See Live Source Code

DeFi Application

This was a personal project that allowed me to get my foot into the door of Decentralised Finance (DeFi) applications. This consisted of building a Decentralised Exchange application, that allowed for the user to stake and unstake their coins into a liquidity pool. This helped become familiar with Solidity - a smart contract language for the Ethereum blockchain - and allowed me to become slightly familiar with using middleware to connect your smart contract (backend) to a front end. It was built using Solidity, Web3.js and React - implementing end to end development.

See Live Source Code

Rock, Paper, Sciscors Game

This was one of my first projects building something with the use of JavaScript with HTML and CSS. It helped me improve and develop my logical thinking and programmatic thinking. Images were incorporated within the project, with there being a user and a CPU, with the user’s turn being generated through what the user selects in the interface and the CPU’s turn being generated through a random math function - which randomly generates a return value between 1 and 3, return either rock, paper or scissors, depending on the value.

See Live Source Code
